cell.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

FROM

div.head: Orient-Royal Mail Line.
div.p: OUTWARD to AUSTRALIA.
R.M.S. “Oroya" will leave Suez about November 16
R.M.S "Ortona" will leave Suez about November 30.
HOMEWARD to NAPLES, MARSEILLES, GIBRALTAR, PLYMOUTH, LONDON, TILBURY.
R.M.S. "Orient" will leave Port Said November 19
R.M.S. “Orentes" will leave Port Said December 3

Return tickets are not issued, but passengers paying the full fare are allowed an abatement of one-third off fare back if return voyage be made within four months of arrival, or abatement of 20 o/o if return voyage be made within six months of arrival.
Agents, Cairo: Thomas Cook & Son, Ltd. ; Alexandria : R. J. Moss & Co.
For all imformation apply to Wm. STAPLEDON & Sons, PORT SAID and PORT-TEWFIK (Suez). 31-12-6

div.head: BIBBY LINE MAIL TWIN-SCREW STEAMERS.
div.p: OUTWARDS to COLOMBO, TUTICORIN, etc., and RANGOON.
S.S. Cheshire 5,775 tons, will leave Suez about November 22nd.
HOMEWARDS to MARSEILLES and LONDON.
S.S.Staffordshire 6,005 tons, will leave Port Said about November 22nd.
Fares from Port Said to Marseilles £12.0.0 ; London £17.0.0 ; Colombo £32.10.0 ; Rangood £37.10.0
Fitted with Refigerators, Electric Light, Electric Fans and all recent improvements.
EXPERIENCED STEWARDESSES and SURGEONS CARRIED. 12-931
Agents in Cairo: THOS. COOK & SON. For all particulars apply to Suez & Port Said : WM. STAPLEDON & SONS PORT SAID PORT TEWFIK (Suez).

div.head: Deutsche Levante-Linie.
div.p: Mail and Passenger Steamships. Regular three-weekly Service from HAMBURG, via ANTWERP & MALTA, to ALEXANDRIA and vice-versa, admitting goods from all chief German Railway Stations on direct Bill of Landing to ALEXANDRIA and all chief ports of Egypt, Syria, etc., at favourable through rates of DEUTSCHE VERKEHR (traffic).
EXPECTED AT ALEXANDRIA.
S.S. Woglinde Nov 16 from Antwerp.
For tariff and particulars apply to ADOLPHE STROSS, Alexandria, Agent.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: The Moss S.S. Company, Ltd.
div.p: For LIVERPOOL calling at MALTA (Messrs. JAMES MOSS & Co. 31, James St, Liverpool, Managers.)

*Second class accommodation only, unless specially reserved.—Fares : Alexandria to Liverpool, 1st, £14 Single, £25 Return. 2nd, £9 Single, £15 Return.—To Malta, 1st, £5 Single, £9 Return, 2nd, £3 Single, £5 Return.—Return tickets available for six months.
S.S. Tabor now on the berth, will sail on or about Saturday, November 17, to be followed by S.S. Ramesess.
S.S Tabor for Havre via Malta to sail about Saturday l5th inst.
Through freight rates on cotton, etc., to Lancashire inland towns, Boston, New York and other U.S.A. towns, obtained on application. Cargo taken by special agreement only.
Passenger Tickets also issued inclusive of Railway fare through to and from Cairo. Particulars on application to
R. J. MOSS & Co., Alexandria, Agents.

div.head: P. HENDERSON & CO’s LINE.
div.p: Steamers leave SUEZ and PORT SAID fortnightly for LONDON or LIVERPOOL direct.
Far, Port Said, to London or Liverpool: £12
S.S. IRRAWADDY 7300 Tons will leave PORT SAID about 18 November
S.S. MANDALAY 6000 Tons will leave PORT SAID about 21st November for Dover.
S.S. PEGU 5800 Tons will leave PORT SAID about 21st November for Dover
Due in LONDON or LIVERPOOL 12 days thereafter.
Apply WORMS & Co., Port Said and Suez. THOS. COOK & SON, (EGYPT) LD., CAIRO ;
G. J. GRACE & CO., ALEXANDRIA.

div.head: INTERNATIONAL SLEEPING AND RESTAURANT CARS COMPANY.

row.cell: Restaurant Car runs every day between Cairo & Alexandria & vice-versa.

div.p: By the 10.15 p.m. train between Cairo and Alexandria and vice-versa a sleeping car is attached every night. Supplement 30 P.T.

row.cell: Daily Restaurant Car Service between Cairo, Ismailia, Port Said & vice-versa.

div.p: Restaurant and Sleeping Cars on Luxor trains:
A Restaurant car and a sleeping car are attached to the 8 p.m. train from Cairo every Monday, Wednesday and Saturday and to the 5.30 p.m. train from Luxor every Tuesday, Thursday and Sunday.

Railway and Sleeping Car tickets can be obtained any number of days ahead at the office of the International Sleeping Car Company in Cairo Station. 1st class Cairo-Luxor P.T. 200. Sleeping Car supplement P.T. 75.

Large and splendidly appointed steamers belonging to the Co. leave Cairo thrice weekly, between November and March, for Luxor, Assouan and Halfa in connection with trains de luxe to Khartoum.-Moderate fares.
Specially Reduced Rates for residents of Egypt by Tourist Services during November and December. First sailing November 13th.
WEEKLY FREIGHT SERVICE FROM CAIRO TO ASSUAN AND HALFA.
Cook's Interpreters in uniform are present at principal Railway Stations and Landing-places in Europe to assist passengers holding their tickets.
Special Steamers and Dahabeahs for private parties.
Special arrangements for tour in PALESTINE, SYRIA and the DESERT; Lowest rates.
Best camp equipment in the country.

div.head: ANGLO-EGYPTIAN BANK LIMITED
div.p: London, Paris, Alexandria, Cairo, Malta, Gibraltar, Tantah, Mansurah and Port-Said.
Subscribed Capital £ 1,520,000, Paid up Capital £ 500,000, Reserve £ 500,000
The Bank undertakes every description of banking business on most favorable conditions.

div.head: CREDIT LYONNAIS
div.p: CAPITAL FRANCS 250,000,000 ENTIEREMENT VERSES
Agences d’Egypte : ALEXANDRIE, LE CAIRE, PORT-SAID.

Le Crédit Lyonnais fait toutes opérations de banque, telles que : Avances sur titres fixes et en compte courant, Avances sur marchandises et consignations, Emission de traités et chèques, Emission de lettres de Crédit, Paiements par télégraphe sur les principales villes de la France èt de l’étranger, Garde de titres Recouvrement d’effets sur l’Egypte et l'étranger ; le Crédit Lyonnais reçoit des fonds en compte de depôt et délivre des bons à échéance fixe au taux de 2 o/o pour 1 an et au-delà. 31-12-906

div.head: COMPTOIR NATIONAL D’ESCOMPTE
div.p: DE PARIS.
CAPITAL: 150,000,000 frs,-£ 6,000,000 FULLY PAID UP. — HEAD OFFICE: 14, Rue Bergere, Paris
Alexandria Branch 11, Rue Cherif Pacha.—40 Branches in Paris, and 112 Throughout France.

Branches in London, Liverpool, Manchester, Morocco, Tunis, East India, Madagascar, Australia, etc. Bills Collected. Deposit Accounts opened at sight & for fixed periods, Advances on securities, in current account. Letters of Credit and Telegraphic Transfers Issued. Foreign Exhange Bought and Sold. Stocks and Valuables received in safe custody. Purchase and Sale of Stock & Shares in Egypt and Abroad. Dividends Collected.

div.p: Capital: £3,000,000. RESERVE (Environ) : £1,340,000. MR. F. T. ROWLATT, Governor

La National Bank of Egypt reçoit des dépots à termes fixes, fait des avances et ouvre des comptes courants sur titres, valeurs et marchandises. Elle s’occupe de l’achat et de la vente d'effets sur l’Etranger, de l'escompte, ainsi que de toutes opérations de Banque. 31-12-906

div.head: CREDIT FRANCO-EGYPTIEN
div.p: Capital 12,500,000 Francs entièrement verses. — Agence d’Alexandrie, 14, Rue Stamboul.

LE CREDIT FRANCO-EGYPTIEN fait toutes opérations de Banque, notamment: Escompte d'effets sur l'Egypte et l'etranger. Avance sur titres.—Garde de titres.—Depots de fonds a vue et à échéance fixe avec intérêts aux taux suivants: 2 1/2 0/0 pour dépôts de 6 mois, 3 0/0 pour dépôts d’un an, 3 1/2 0/0 pour dépôts au délà d’un an. — LE CREDIT FRANCO-EGYPTIEN reçoit des Marchandises en consignation pour la vente et fait des Avances sur Cotons, Grains et autres marchandises. — 28337-10-8-907

div.head: Austrian Lloyd’s Steam Navigation
div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Trieste (Venice).

Weekly Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m. arrive at Brindisi, Tuesday 5 a.m. in time for express to Milan, Lucerne, Paris, Vienna, Berlin, and London, leaving Brindisi 7 a.m. Arrival Trieste Wednesday about 11 a.m. in connection with Train de Luxe Trieste-Vienna-Ostende. Passengers reach London every Friday 4.50 p.m.
Fortnightly Service: Alexandria-Brindisi & Trieste Line.
Steamer leaves Alexandria on or about 10 and 24 October, 7 and 21 November, 5 and 19 December.
Syrian-Cyprus-Caramanian Line.
Steamer leaves Alexandria on or about 8 and 22 October, 5 and 19 November, 3, 17 and 31 December.
Syrian-Caramanian Line.
Steamer leaves Alexandria on or about 1, 15 and 29 October, 12 and 26 November, 10 and 24 December.
Far East Lines.
Departures from Port Said: To Suez, Aden, Bombay, Colombo, Penang, Singapore, Hong-Kong, Shanghai, Yokohama and Kobé, 4 October, 3 November.
To Suez, Aden and Bombay accelerated service about 8 October, 8 Nov., 8 Dec.
To Suez, Aden, Karachi, Colombo, Madras, Rangoon, and Calcutta about 19 Oct, 3, 19 Nov., 19 Dec 4 p.m.
To Suez, Aden, Karachi and Bombay about 13 Nov., 1 Dec (Winter Line).
East African Line.
Departures from Port Said: To Suez, Aden, Mombassa, Zanzibar, Beira, Delagoa-Bay, and Durban about 3 Oct., 2 Nov., 3 Dec..
For information apply to the Agents, Alexandria, Port Said and Suez, Thos. Cook & Son, Ld., Leon Heller, Cairo Agent, 24, Sharia Maghraby, (Telephone 192), Cairo; F. Tedeschi, Helouan.

div.head: SUDAN GOVERNMENT RAILWAYS.
div.p: CAIRO-KHARTOUM SUMMER MAIL SERVICE.--SUMMER TIME-TABLE 1906.
Commencing from 1st of April, 1906, until further notice

‡Sleeping and Dining Cars. — During the month of April Sleeping and Dining Care trains leave Cairo for Luxor on Wednesdays, Mondays and Saturdays at 6.30 p.m. and Luxor for Cairo on Sundays, Tuesdays and Thursdays at 6.30 p.m.

From 1st of May 1908, these trains will be suppressed, but Dining and Sleeping Care will be attached to the ordinary night Tains from Cairo and Luxor three times a week, on the same above mentioned days. 14-6-907

div.head: THE NATIONAL HOTEL, Cairo
div.p: One of the finest and most up-to-date Hotels in the Metropolis. Situated in Sharia Soliman Pasha, the very centre of the healthiest and most fashionable quarter. Stands in its own grounds with garden and lawn tennis grounds at back. Over 350 rooms and 5 saloons. Magnificent salle à manger. Handsome covered promenade verandah, 80 yards long. Highest class cuisine, electric light throughout, and lifts. English comforts. Rooms and apartments at prices to suit everyone. For further particulars apply to GENERAL MANAGER, Cairo.

div.head: Municipalite d'Alexandrie
div.p: AVIS La Municipalité met on adjudicatioa la fourniture de ciment nécessaire à 868 Services pendant l'année 1907.
Le cantionnement es fixé à L E. 30 (trente.
Le cabier des charges est déposé an Barean de la Voirie où il peut être consulté par les intéressés tous les jours de 9 h. midi, les Hours fériés excepté.
Les offras devront être adressées sous pli cacheté à Monsieur l'Admiristra!enr de la Municipalité, avant le 4 Décembre 1905.
Elles pourront également étre déposées en séance de la Délégation le même jour à 5h. p m.
L'enveloppe devra porter en ontre la men tion "Soumission pour fourniture de ciment.

Le cautionnement on le roca d'ade banque. d'après les cor ditions du cabier des charges, devra être remis éparément au Se: viie de lo Comptabilité Générale, avant l'ouverture der offres et au pios tard le 4 Décembre à midi.
Toute offre qai ne remplit pas les conditions ci-dessus sera écartée. ..

ADVERTISEMENTS.—P.T. 4 per line. Minimum charge P.T. 20. Births, Marriages, or Deaths, not exceeding three lines, P.T. 20. Every additional line P.T. 10. Notices in news column P.T. 20 per line. Contracts entered into for standing advertisements.

div.head: The Egyptian Gazette
div.p: An English Daily Newspaper, Established in 1880.
Editor & Manager: R. Snelling.
Price: One Piastre Tariff.
THURSDAY, November 8, 1906.
DOES PAN-ISLAMISM EXIST?

In discussing the Pan-Islamic bogey, which the Head season revived from a long slumber, the Constantinople correspondent of the "Tribune remarks that the evidence brought forward in support of the contention that "Yildiz Palace has become the head centre of a great organization which aims at embracing the whole Mussulman world, and has certainly succeeded in spreading its ramifications bver a great part of it” utterly fails to support it

The strongest evidence adduced," he says is derived from recent occurrences in Egypt. What it amounts to is this: that Egypt having been taken out of the control of Turkey, the ulema of that country and the Moslem population generally were urged, both on the occasion of the naval demonstrations regarding Tabah and the unfortunate 1 incident at Denishwai, to show their dis
satisfaction with British interference in Egypt, and that to a certain extent they showed such digestisfaction. But there is no necessary connexion between such display and a PanIslamic movement.

"Everyone can readily understand that the substitution of British for Turkish control in Egypt gave rise to very great irritation among the Turkish official class, both here and in Egypt. It could not have been otherwise. Recall the circumstances. Egypt was by far the largest and the most important of the tributary states under Turkish rule. When England first determined to land troops in Egypt, the Sultan was invited to send his troops and to make the occupation a, joint one. For reasons well known he refused, and, to the astonishment of Yildiz, British troops entered alone. Abdul Hamid soon recognized that 'the blow to his reputation as suzerain was heavy ; and Mr. "Gladstone and Lord Salisbury having each pledged themselves again and again to leave Egypt, Sir Henry Drummond Wolff was sent to negotiate thin conditions on which British troops should withdraw A convention was agreed to. The last soldier was to be out of the county within seven years. Then a blunder way made, owing to external influences upon Yildiz, and the convention which Drummond Wolff had drawn, and which was accepted by the Grand Vizier and by England, was rejected by the Sultan. ..

"England had now just cause to be offended, and when & year or so later Abdul Hamid proposed that negotiations should be reopened on the basis of the Drummond Wolff Convention Lord Salisbury refused. From that time, or, to be more precise, from the time when France took possession of Tunis, no statesman of either party renewed the declaration that England would leave Egypt. Add to all this the facts that the enormous prosperity of Egypt has produced awkward comparisons with the backwardness of Turkey, that there is a large Druse and Moslem emigration from Syria into Egypt, and that many Turkish officials who were enrichin selves at the cost of the Egyptians have lost their means of plunder, and it will be seen that the irritation of Yildiz does not require the suggestion of Pan-Islamism. to explain its existence. | "It is said tha, Islamism during the last quarter of a century. has made many new converts, especially, indeed almost exclusively, in Central Africa. No one to my knowledge has ever suggested that the conversion of fetish worshippers to a belief in one God has been the result of missionary efforts from Turkey. But, assuming the statement to be true, it is far from showing either that there is a Pan-Islamic movement, or that such a movement is directed by. Abdul Hamid, Moslemismi being, liko Christianity, & great missionary religion, there is in it, and always has been, a movement for its propagation. Since the time of Mahomed it has constantly happened that its great and ennobling monotheistic teaching has appealed to uncivilized men. If more converts have been made of late than in preceding years, it is because the opening up of Africa has brought the black races into contact with Arab and other Moslem traders. In this limited sense there has been an increase in the number of Moslems. But to assert that this shows that there is a Pan-Islamic movement beyond the ordinary one which has been going on during centuries is unwarranted by the evidence.

"The massacre of Christians in Bulgaria and the unparalleled slaughter of Armenians are adduced as evidence of Pan-Islamism. As to the first, it took place before Abdul Hamid came to the throne. It must, therefore, be excluded as evidence against any such movement directed by him. He, however, must bear the reproach of the merciless slaughter of Armenians, and tho cruol persecution to which that pel ple has been subjected. But the outrages which all Europe justly condemned were not due to any Pan-Islamic movement. Though thousands were slaughtered by orders from Yildiz, the motive cannot be called reli. gious. The outrages were participated in by a Moslem population from motives mainly of plunder. The justification offered to the barbarians' who killed their neighbours and stole their property was that their intended victims were in revolt. The statement was in almost every case false. It was, of course, readily believed by people to whom it furnished & legal excuse for stealing all that they could lay their hands on. The motive was not so much religious or fanatical as mercenary. Moslems rarely, if ever, killed Armenians merely because they were Christians, but mostly to gain possession of what. those in authority told them they might take. Whatever were the motives which led to the Armenian massacres, and it is not difficult to find them, they do not give evidence of any Pan-İslamic movement.

"The construction of a railway to Mecca is adduced as one of the results of the Pan. Islamic movement. It is due in part, possibly altogether, to the initiative of Abdul Hamid. But anyone who knows what was the cost of the annual pilgrimage to Mecca, pilgrimage there being one of the "five pillars" of Islam and therefore obligatory, will marvel that such & trailway was not thought 6f long before. The marvel will be the greater when it is remembered that for fifty years Turkey has been constantly at war with Arab tribes. The only other evidence adduced in favour of Pan-Islamism is the attempt made in Afghanistan, and, perhaps, elsewhere, to lead the Moslems of those countries to make common cause with Turkey against Great Britain. Such attempts were undoubtedly made. In 1881 or 1882, when Lord Dufferin was here, he learned that a newspaper called Peik

Islam" was being printed at Yildiz for circulaItion in India during our troubles withi Afghanistan. Lord Dufferin was essentially a strong Ambassador, and he had a strong Liberal Government behind him. The representations made by him at Yildiz at once put a stop to all'attempts of that kind. It should be remem. bered that at the time there was very great soreness at Yildiz against England. The firmness of Mr. Goschen over the Dulcigno question was only one of several causes of such irritation. That an attempt was made to use the co-religionists of the Turks against us was not unnatural, but such attempt does not show the existence of a Pan-Islamic sentiment."
Cairo Circulating Library.
The Library will be closed on Friday, 9th instant, H.M. the King's Birthday. 28813-1

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL.
div.p: Cordon College.
Today is the fourth anniversary of the Opening of Gordon College, Khartoum, by Lord Kitchener.
Railway Administration.
A meeting of the Board of the Egyptian State Railways will be held on Monday at the Ministry of the Interior under the presidency of Mustapha Pasha Febmy. Lellot el Kadr.

The ceremony of the Lailet el Kadr, or the - Night of Power," will take place at the Mohamed Aly Morqne, Cairo, next Tuesday, when the Khedive will be represented by Prince Mohamed Aly King's Birthday Parade at Cairo i n

To prevent confusion, it has been notified to ut by the military authorities that no carriages will be admitted to the carriage enologore of Abdeen-square to-morrow, por individuals to che reserved enclosures, apless sickets of admission' are produced to the police on duty.
1 Azhar University

The Senate of Al Azhar University met at Cairo the day before yesterday under the presidency of Sheikh Mobamed Shakir, acting Chancellor, when the transfers, and appointments of officials of the University were dealt with. The budget of the Alexandria board of ulema: was approved, and will shortly be Submitted to the Khedive.
Embezzlement at Fashn.
It is reported from Fushn that Mastapha Effendi Ahmed, cashier of the markaz, disappeared from that town on the 27th olt., and that on the examination of his books and the cash it
Was found that L.E. 90 were missing. Mustapha's wife admitted that her husband bad had Bach a sum in his possession and that he took Et away with him when he left that morning.
Egyptian Ivory in London.

The extent and exceptionally fiae quality of the supply of Egyptian descriptions was the chief feature at the quarterly ivory sales held in London last week. Of the 63} tons on offer, 377 tons ware Egyptian (26) tons Alexandrian, 104 tons Malta descriptions), this being the largest supply offered for a considerable time past. The competition was general, soft large and medium tusks on the average advercing £8 to £15 per cwt., and hard £10 to £15 per cwt.
Repair of the Isla.

Messrs. Caird and Co, Greenock, who are shortly abdát to launch the Nore, the last of the four mail and passenger steamers for the Peninsular and Oriental Steam Navigation Company (the three already launched being the Nile, Namor, and the Nyanza), are about to put in band for extensive repair the same company's leis. It is understood that this steamship company will shortly invite tenders for the construction of five Jarge fast twin-screw mail steamers. The new vessels will be improvements on the Mongolia, which is of 9.500 tons gross register, and was built and engine - by Messrs. Caird in 1903.
London Koopeniok Case.

A rival of the captain of Koepenick appeared in the West London Police Court last week on & charge of obtaining money by false pretences. He gave his name as Edward Clarke, and described himself in court as an architect, bat Mr. George Bernett, who proge pated, said he had been posing for a long time 29 a retired colonel of the King's Rifles. He talked fluently on military.subjects, and described vividly bis exploits in Egypt and the Sodan. When he met public men like the Mayor of Hammersmith in the street be Always greeted them with a military salute and said "Good morning," and they always Acknowledged the salate. Clarke, who admitted that he was not a colonel, declared that the money was given in payment for work he did For Mr. Barnett. He was committed for trial at the Old Bailey.
The Theatrical Season.

The first theatrical performances, of the Beagon 'have been given in Alexandria by a Greek company and in Cairo by an Italian company. Soon we are promised some enjoyable evenings by some French companies. For all those who like the theatre what 8 delicate pleasure it would be to be capable of appreciating and comparing the different bearties of. all these theatrical pieces in so many language-! "The Berlitz School of Languages of Cairo (1, Sharia Kamel) and of Alexandria (12 rue Rosette). pata it in the power of its pupils in in a very short time to enjoy this best and most refined of distractions. (Advt.)

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: 'The Moss liner Seti sailed from Liverpool yesterday afternoon, and is due bere 'on the 21st int with passengers, Dails, and general cargo.
The Moss lemur Menes emailed yesterday afternoon for Manchester, via Malta, .with Passengers, mails, and general cargo, including 5,469 bales cotton.
The Messageries Maritimes SS. Equator, which left Alexandria on Saturday at 3 a m., arrived at Marveilles yesterday at 2 p.m.
'The S.S. Ocean Prince lett Malta yesterday with passengers and general cargo, and is due to arrive at Alexandria on Sunday. .
The 8.8. Asiatic Prince left Manchester yesterday with pa-sengers and general cargo, and is due to arrive at Alexandria on or about the 23rd inst.

div.head: UPPER NILE SURVEY.
div.p: GONDOKORO TO LAKE ALBERT.

Of the grant of L E. 15,000 for a levelled survey of the Nile from Gondokoro to Lake Albert nothing has yet been spent, but it is hoped that the work will be taken in hand this winter. The kendies of the Public Works Department for the several projects for controlling the Upper Nile are progressing with such rapidity that it seems probable that, in a year's time at most, it will be in a position to advise the Egyptian Government as to a definite selection from among them. Meanwhile the authorities have been much bandicapped by their lack of accurate knowledge regarding the levels of the river throughout its course, more especially from its sources to the second Cataract. Much has been done, and much is being done to rectify their ignorance in this respect. In Egypt proper, precision levelling is in progress. In the Cataract region, the survey parties above mentioned are at work, while, between Khartoam and Gondokoro, the officers of the Sudan Irrigation Service are carrying a line of levels up the White Nile and the Bohr-el-Gebel. South of Gondokoro,however, there is a complete blank, beyond the rough surveys of the river made by Sir William Garstin and others travellers. No levels exist and, beyond the information afforded by a certain number of barometric readings - avowedly inaccurate - we know nothing whatever regarding the slope and fall of the river. It is this portion of the Nile valley then that it is desired to have surveyed and levelled, at an early date.

Apart from the desirability of the work upon technical grounds-seeing that the construction of a regulator at the Albert lake may possibly be taken in hand simultaneously to the improvement of the channel in the swamps-such a survey is highly desirable upon a scientific grounds. Considering the importance of the Nile to Egypt and to the Sudan, the non-completion of such an undertaking must be held somewhat as a reproach to the administration of Public Works in Egypt.
The work will be commenced this winter. Levels will be carried across from the Victoria to the Albert lake, and thence down the Bahr-el-Gebel to Gondekoro.

As the water-level cf Lake Victoria bas been a connected by spirit-levelling with the sea at Mombasa, we shall, when the chain is completed, have a complete circuit of levels from the Mediterranean-up the Nile valley and down the Uganda railway-to the Indian Ocean.

div.head: MECCA PILGRIMAGE.
div.p: QUARANTINE RESTRICTIONS.

Mr. Morley, replying in the House of Commons on Thursday last to Ms. Rees, who asked whether the Turkish Government had agreed to the removal by the Government of India of the quarantine restrictions imposed at Bombay upon Mohammedan pilgrims to Mecca, said :-The quarantine regulations in question were imposed, and have been removed, by the Government of India on their own initiative and without previous reference to the Tarkish Government. They have been discontinued, as they were found to be supercious for the detection of plague while injurious to the comfort and health of the pilgrims. The Turkish Govərnment has been fully informed of these considerations, and of the precautionary measures which have been substituted for quarantide at Bombay.

div.head: BRITISH ENGINEERS IN EGYPT.
div.p: The Cairo correspondent of "African Engineering" says:- It is satisfactory to note that an increasing number of men are being brought out from home to fill official positions as engineers. This is, perhaps, a reason for the outcry which has lately been started in their
local Press about corruption in the Irrigation service. I would like to say at once that, amid so many temptations, a less corruptible body of men does not exist than the English official

in Egypt which is accounted for by Lord Cromer's care in selecting his men. Britons are notoriously the poorest men in Egypt, but the doings of the Levantine underlings in all branches of the public service, would well repay strict inquiry. The way in which numbers of them have grown rich while holding official positions is nothing short of marvellous, and their places might well be filled with Englishmen, to the advantage of the country and in the interests of true economy.

div.head: EGYPTIAN COTTON IN INDIA.
div.p: Apropos of the cultivation of Egyptian cotton in Sind, it appears on official authority, says the 'Capital" (Calcatta), that one of the principal difficulties the zemindar has to contend with is that of obtaining an adequate apply of labour for the cultivation of the staple. The ordinary labourer in Sind, it is said. dislikes the additional and unfamiliar trouble involved in the proper cultivation of Egyptian cotton. The zemindar is therefore hard put to secure efficient labour and has to pay well for it, and to take unwanted risks. The Bombay authorities have accordingly intimated to the Bombay mill industry that if they desire to see the Sind Egyptian cotton experiments accomplish the great results anticipated for them they must cooperate with Government in risking a little expenditure in money and effort in securing the crop and so encouraging the cultivator. A promising feature in the position is that the Bombay Government are hopeful of getting railway communication into the heart of the tract where Egyptian cotton is being grown in Sind at an fi early date.

div.head: A NEW EGYPTIAN COMPANY,
div.p: EGYPTIAN GINNING and COTTON, LTD.

A new Egyptian company, called the Egyptian Ginning and Cotton, Limited, was registered on October 27th, by Blyth, Datton, Hartley and Blyth, 1:2 Gresham House, B. C. with a capital of £250,000, in £1 shares. Its objects are: To acquire the Egyptian patent rights belonging to Prior Fibres Consolidated, Limited, to carry on the business of cotton ginners, balers and pressers, wool burrers, manufacturers of machinery for the ginning of cotton, the barring of wool, the cleaning of fibres, the spinning of threads and the napping of goods, etc.; and to adopt an agreement between Prior Fibres Consolidated, Limited, of the one part, and H. Hartley of the other part. The signatories are :--
Shares.
D.F. Shillington, 31, Spencer Park, Wands.
worth, S.W. merchant........... 1
J. H. Osborne, 4, Lloyd's Avenge, E.C., . merchant. ... ... ... .. ... 1
Capt. E. C. Harington, Norfolk House,Norfolk Street, W.CI ............ 1
A. H. Rowe, Harefield Grove, Harefield, Middlesex. Chairman of Egyptian
Dredging Company, Limited, Cairo 1
Surgeon-Ganeral V, V. Gallwey, Janior
United Service Club, London...... 1
F. T. Murdoch, Mansourah, Egypt, engineers ...1
Col. N. E. P. Gordon, C.B., 63, St. James .

No initial public issue. The first directors (to number not less than three nor more than nine) are to be appointed by the signatories. Qualification, £500 shares or stock. Remuneration (except managing directors); £250 each per annum (£100 extra for the chairman). The directors (including managing directors) are also to receive 10 per cent. of the surplus profits available for distribution after 10 per cent. dividend has been paid, divisible.

div.head: THE SUCRERIES COMPANY..
div.p: The new management in Cairo of the Sacreries d'Egypte has advised the board in Paris of its success in effecting economies representing an annual saving of £400,000. A total output for the year of between 550,000 and 600,000 sacks is anticipated, which is calculated to produce a net profit of 5,000,000, this sum being sufficient not only to cover the interest on the mortgage bonds, ordinary debentures, and deferred shares, amounting to 4,500,00f. In all, but to leave & sum of 500,000f. for
distribution on the ordinary shares.

div.head: DEAN BUTCHER RETIRING.
div.p: We greatly regret to learn of the impending resignation of the Very Rev. Dean Batcher, D.D., who has held the chaplaincy of All Saints' Church, Cairo, for the past twenty-six years, during which period be has endeared himself
to the hearts of the English community. We Understand that Dean Batcher's health has,

of late, not been satisfactory and it is already known to our readers that he fell ill during his recent holiday in Switzerland. From this, we are glad to say, he has recovered, but he doubtless feels compelled to resign on account of his advanced years, which must prevent him from carrying on his work with that great zeal and energy, which he has amply demonstrated during his chaplaincy in Cairo. Dean Butcher came to Egypt from Shanghai, where he had ministered to the spiritual wants of the Angliean community since 1864, and previous to that he had held curacies at St. Clement's Danes and St. Paul's, Hammersmith. He is known to all of us as a deep scholar; he is a Fellow of the University of Durham, at which University he gained first class in classics. His writings, too, are well-known to all Anglo-Egyptians, the latest of which, "The Oriflamme in Egypt," he attracted a great many readers.

div.head: POULTRY CHOLERA.
div.p: The "Vérité" of Port Said calls the attention of the sanitary inspector of that town to the serious recrudescence of cholers among fowls, and advises the prohibition of the importation of fowls from Syria and Cyprus, as these on arrival in this country are frequently found to be diseased.
The other day Captain Moore, of the Port Suid police, made a tour of inspection through in the market and confiscated a considerable number of poultry suffering from cholera.

We might note that this disease has been prevalent in Egypt for more than a couple of years, and those upon whom have fallen the duties of housekeeping or catering long since discovered that it was only safe to accept poultry which was delivered to them alive Killed and dressed Egyptian fowl should never be accepted, as some doubt must remain as to what death was due to, and it is by no means uncommon for an animal to die from cholera between the purchaser's shop and the purchaser's house.

div.head: FAITH OF THE OLD EGYPTIANS
div.p: In the course of an interview in last week "Christian Commonwealth,” Mr. H. Rider Hag on gard is reported as speaking as follows: "Mere negation and destructivism cannot possibly do any good to a race doomed to wander from darkness into darkness. Deprive man of the hope taught by all the creeds, and what is left, especially when he begins to grow old and has done with ambitions ?... The happiest people that the earth bag known were also the most absolute believers in the indefinite continuance of individual life. I mean the old Egyptians."

div.head: NOTES FROM KENEH.
div.p: DENGUE FEVER PREVALENT
(FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT.)
Keneb, November 5.
Dengue fever is very prevalent in the Keneh district, and nearly everybody in the town is suffering or has suffered from it in more or, less acute forms. There is also a certain amount of diphtheria.
S.P.C.A. Branch.

Than to the initiative taken by Mr. Å. W. Hazell, inspector in the Ministry of the Interior, and Mr. C. W. Warner, of the Agricultural Bank,a local branch of the S.P.C.A. has been established here. Mr. Hazell and Mr. Warner were ably seconded by the sub mandir, Abdul Halim Bey. A meeting was held at the moudirieh this morning and the appeals of Mr. Hazell apd Abdul Halim Bey were liberally responded to, L.E. 275 being handed over to the treasurer. A hospital for animals is to be built behind the Post Office:
National Bank.
An agency of the National Bank of Egypt is than to be opened on the 15th inst. at Luxor, of which Mr. Bernard Losco has been appointed that manager.
Water Supply
It is more than a year ago since money was granted to the municipality for the extension

To that of the town's water installation, and yet there are no signs of the work being commenced. Much dissatisfaction is expressed at the procrastinating methods of the municipality, and the inhabitants are hoping that the Ministry of the Interior will take the matter up when their attention is drawn to it by this protest

div.head: TELEPHONES IN EGYPT.
div.p: ALEXANDRIA.COMES FIRST. ;

In Sir William Garstin's report for 1905 there are some interesting figures showing the number of subscribers to the Telephone Company and the capacity of the boards in the various towns in which the service exists.
It is somewhat curious that Alexandria, ed to lo

lor whose population is considerably less than that of Cairo, should have 216 more subscribers than the capital. The capacity of the Alexandria board, too, only provides for another 96 subscribers, whereas the Cairo board can accommodate 412 extra pegs. Port Said subscribers only number 177, Tantah has 112, and Suez 88.
There are in all 4,243 subscribers, of which Alexandria's share amounts to 1,924, and the
number of calls through the exchange averages ending 12 calls per subscriber per day, or about 50,916 calls over the entire system.

div.head: WRESTLING AT CAIRO
div.p: Tuesday night's wrestling matches at the Theatre Abbas, Cairo, were decidedly interesting. The second bout between Schakmann and Limonsin was the event of the evening. It terminated in the overthrow of the former after half an hour's very keen and vigorous struggle. Van der Berg beat Noël after 15 minutes' good wrestling.

We notice that "Al Moayad" blames the crowd of spectators for their excessive partisanship. Our confrère's sporting contributor seizes the occasion to deplore the absence of athletics from Egyptian life, remarking that the Greek (sic) adage, "a sound mind in a healthy body," is not sufficiently regarded in Egypt.

div.head: PROVINCIAL CHURCH SERVICES.
div.p: Below are the English Church Sunday services at Mansonrah and Tantah for November. Last Sunday, though the chaplain only arrived from leave in time to give notice locally in each place, a few gathered together in each church. There were 8 communicants at Mansourah in the morning.

div.head: KING'S BIRTHDAY.
div.p: By kind permission of Lient.-Colonel R.C.C. Cox, commanding, and officers 2nd Batt. Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers, the Band will play the following programme of music on the terrace of the Grand Continental Hotel from 4 to it is by 6 p.m. on Friday in honour of the King's birthday. March --Edward our King-Asch
Overture-The Merry Monarch-Herold
Mazurka Militaire Sabre au Clair--Missa
Valse--The Choristers-Phelps
Selection--Songs of England --arr. Godfrey
Patrol - The Roso, Shamrock & Thistle-Sousa
Air de Ballet-Les Etoiles-Eaton
Selection - The Belle of New York Kerker
Regimental March.---Khedivial Anthem.
God save the King,
R. WATSON RAMSEY, Bandmaster.

div.head: EGYPTIAN GOlD DEMAND.
div.p: THE COUNTRY'S MARVELLOUS.
PROSPERITY.

The large withdrawals of gold from the Bank of England for Egypt have formed an import ant topic for discussion in the London financial Press during the past few weeks. In a recent article on the subject, the "Financier" gives the following able statement of the facts regarding the position :--
The only trouble in Egypt, financially, is the rapidly growing prosperity of the country.

In connection with the recent large withdrawals of gold from the Bank of England on Egyptian account there has been some apprehension that more of the metal might have to go the same way--even large amounts--and that, consequently, more stringent conditions than ever might supervere in the London money market. As the result of enquiries in banking-circles connected with Egypt it may be said that, although further remittances of gold to that country may have to be made, it is not very likely that they will aggregate more than three-quarters of a million sterling, or, at the outside, a million. Also it does not follow that the whole of this will be drawn from England. France, having, actually and relatively, a much larger supply of gold available than the United Kingdom, could, if need be, send it to Egypt with less effort. It is not expected that this will happen on a large scale, but it is probable there will be some consignments from that quarter.

A representative of the "Financier," in the course of several interviews with banking authorities, elicited an interesting exposé of the situation with respect to the need for gold in Egypt in relation to the cotton crop One gentleman, whose description of the true position of affairs may be taken as typical, said:-

"There has been, seemingly, quite a mistaken idea as to the meaning of those consignments of gold to Egypt. Some financial writers appear to be in ignorance of the fact that every year at this season large consignments of gold are made to Cairo, mainly in connection with the cotton crop. It is so expected and so regular an operation that it usually excites the very slightest notice. This time, however, for two or three reasons, it has been made very conspicuous. It happened that the gold was withdrawn at such a moment and in such a way that it was associated with the declaration of a 6 per cent. Bank rate. And the total amount withdrawn up to date is more than it has been hitherto.
"There are several reasons for this, but there are two in particular, The Egyptian

cotton crop this year is a very big one, estimated at seven millions of cantars. Consequently that fact alone would mean more money-more gold brought into the cöntry, to pay for it - than has been the case hitherto. Then there was the partial destruction of the cotton crop in the United States. It is impossible to say even now what the approximate damage really amounted to. The bull operators of course made the most of their opportunity and put up prices as high as possible, but the damage was severe, and there will be a certain shortage; consequently a rise in the price of cotton is a legitimate result. The quotations for Egyptian cotton have been
considerably affected, so that not only shall we have a very large output, but a higher price for the product. This will mean a larger amount of gold than heretofore to ‘lift' the crop.

"In those circumstances it requires no argument to show that Egypt will, during the next twelve months, be in a position to make perhaps greater progress than she has ever done before in any one year. At any rate, she will be exceedingly prosperous, and that property will, naturally, have a certain stimulating effect in this country."
"May I ask if you can tell me how it was that the Bank of England appeared not to be aware of these requirements of Egypt until, as it were, the last moment.?"

"I suppose that the management do not or in this case did not take sufficient cognisance of what was going on in the outside financial world beyond what was communicated to them officially. If they had possessed the knowledge it is to be surmised they would have put up the rate 5 per cent. some weeks ago. That would have been far better from every point of view, and would have avoided the equeeze which has been brought about by the 6 percent. rate-an abnormal one which, it is to be hoped, will not last very long."
"Do you consider it probable that the success of this season's cotton crop in Egypt will - stimulate the planting of a large acreage ?"
"Yes; I should say it certainly will."
"May there not be a consequent slump in the price for the 1907 orop ?"

"It by no means follow. At present the fine | long staple cotton grown in Egypt cannot be raised successfully in any other country in the world. And I believe the demand for it is steadily growing. Not only in Europe, but in the United States, Egyptian cotton is being used in constantly increasing quantities.".
"If the price were reduced, do you think the consumption would be much increased?

"I doubt it. But at present there appears to be no need to reduce the price. There are, of course, different qualities of the fibre produced in Egypt, but the best appears it be always sure of a market. In the Sadat there is a certain small quantity of short staple cotton grown, more like iho American variety but I do not know whether it is exported a all; the entire quantity raised is very trifling I am not an expert on cotton, but I understand the cultivators consider the soil and climate of Egypt particularly adapted for the long staples.
description, and as this is always likely to command the higher price there can be little

doubt that it is the variety which will be planted as fresh ground is broken. Personally, I look forward to the indefinite development of Egypt for many years to come, and to the employment of vast sums of English money there for beyond anything which has yet been done. The exports of our gold to Cairo should be regarded As a matter for congratulation.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Prince Ibrahim Pasha Hilmy, uncle of the Khedive, has purchased at Pausilippo the Villa Rendel, a magnificent structure overlooking the bay of Naples and situated in a beautiful part close to the sea. His Highness intends to pass the winter there.

The Ministers and Sir Vincent Corbett, the Financial Adviser, are coming down to Alexandria tomorrow, and will be granted an audience by the Khedive at Ras el Tin Palace. After obtaining his Highness's sanction to Various schemes, the officials will return to Cairo in the evening.
The Countess of Cromer left Marseilles last Wednesday for Port Said by the Bibby liner Derbyshire and arrived at Cairo late last night. We are glad to say that the Countess is in excellent health.
Lady Gorst is arriving at Port Said shortly. by the P. &0. S.S. Macedonia on a visit to Egypt.

Mr. Maneteld de C. Findlsy, Councillor of the British Agency in Cairo, had the honour of being received by the King at Buckingham Palace yesterday week Curiously enough, in the Court Circular announcement of the audience, the Agency is described as "his Majesty's Embassy."
Sir Aogastus Hemming and Lady and Miss Hemming are leaving London for Egypt about the middle of the month.

Dr. Porphyrios Logothetis, the Archbishopof Mount Sinai, the famous monastery renowned for its precious and unique manuscripts, is now in Paris on his way to England. After paying a short visit to London he will go to Cambridge, where the degree of D.D.L. was conferred on him two years ago.
Macauley Bey returned to Cairo yesterday..
Dr. Graham has returned from Europe.
Kaimakam Ali Bey Ismail has been appointed commandant of the Khedivial Body Guard - ice Abdallab Bey Fikri, transferred to the
Meieb.
Abdel Khalih Bsy Sarwat has been appointed director of administration to the Ministry of Justice.

We regret to announce the impending retirement of Mr. P. P. Graves, our Cairo Correspondent, from the staff of the "Egyptian Gazette." Mr. Graves has accepted an important correspondentship on the staff of the London "Times."
M. Shakri Ghanem, the author of 'Antar," has returned.

St. Andrew's Church, Alexandris, on Tuesday, the marriage took place of Mr. Thomas Hood, F.S.I., resident manager of the Gharbieh Land Co. Ris el-Khalig, to Miss Mary Todd Wilson, daughter of the late John Wilson, of Edington, Mains, Dons. The Rev. H. P. Reid officiated.
Mr. A Paulkner, the chief accountant in ce London of Messrs. Thos. Cook & Son, arrived in Cairo from England last night.

Amongst the latest arrivals at the Eastern Exchange Hotel, Port Said, are : Miss A. Eyre, Mr. and Mrs. F. W. Sykes, Mr. and Mrs. Psycha, Mr. G. H. Sharmap, Mr. G. B. Ireland, Mr. E. C. Pennefather, Mr. H. Boyd Carpenter, Mr. M. C. Stubbs, Mr. Etohogoyeao, Mr. M. E. Bandmann and party, Mr. J. F. G. Hopkins, Mr. K.C. Hopkins, Mr. D. / Lawson, Rev. H. G. Hopkins, Miss Forsythe, Miss G. Hill, Mr. and Mrs. Dono, Mr. and Mrs. Baxter, Capt. and Mrs. Lyone, Capt. and Mrs. Haldane, Sir Malcolm Mollwraith, Mr. R. G. Brunton, Mr. E Rosi, Mr. and Mrs. Tchavooobian, Misk. L. A. C. Borney, Miss Lomax, Miss Barnett, Miss Markham, Mr. B. A. Harrison, Mr. J. R. Campbell, Mr. and Mrs. C. K. Beasley, and party," Dr. H. Nolar, Lieat. Col. and Mrs:: Garner, Miss Hookey, - Miss Smith, Miss Hossack, Mr. and Mrs. F. C. Berger, Mr. J. C. Black, Mr. and Mrs. Cooter, Mr. J. Bell, Miss Bell, Mr. P. O. Walker, Abou Chanab Bey, Zuly Bay, Hassan Rida Bey, Mr. G. Ostini, Canon and Mrs. Ponnefather, Miss B. Hunter, Mr. Warland, Mr. and Mre. W. S. Lambert, Mr. and Mrs. J. Cree, Miss Cree, Mr. Persley, Mg. A. K. Lacke.
